awd_titl_txt: Workshop - Understanding Mathematical Explanation: Uniting Philosophical and Educational Perspectives; Spring 2020; New Brunswick, NJ
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a workshop to develop new insights about the nature of mathematical explanation by bringing together philosophers of mathematics, epistemologists, psychologists, and mathematics educators to discuss how developments in their own fields could meaningfully contribute to the development of an account of mathematical explanation that unites these multiple perspectives. Invited speakers and attendees will be given several opportunities during the workshop (in panels, working groups, and informal settings) to engage in significant work on cross-cutting themes. The workshop organizers also plan to use targeted advertisement in local schools of education and school districts to attract interest among pre- and in-service teachers to attend the conference. As a broader impact, workshop organizers expect that these results will have a significant impact on educational work on mathematical explanation, and that this will in turn lead to new understandings and teaching methods that will ultimately impact teachers and students of mathematics at all educational levels.

The notion of explanation is central to both philosophy and education. These disciplines have made significant developments concerning the role and character of explanations in scientific inquiry and in the classroom. However, the notion of explanation in the field of mathematics has proved to be particularly challenging; both philosophers and educators are unclear about what is needed in a mathematical explanation so that it goes beyond merely demonstrating that some mathematical phenomenon is so to explaining why it is so. Since here has been little influence of philosophical accounts of mathematical explanation in educational research, and vice versa, the workshop organizers expect that bringing together experts in these fields and some related fields in a workshop setting has potential to advance our knowledge and understanding of the notion of mathematical explanation in the both fields. They plan to enhance that potential by inviting speakers who are not only experts in the study of explanation and understanding from their own disciplinary perspective, but also open to crossing traditional disciplinary boundaries and to using different theoretical and methodological traditions in their own work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The notion of explanation is central to both philosophy and education. These disciplines have made significant strides in understanding the role of explanations in scientific inquiry and the classroom. However, the notion of explanation in the field of mathematics has proved to be particularly challenging. For instance, philosophers and educators alike have struggled to identify the features of an argument that not only demonstrates that some mathematical phenomenon is the case, but also explains why it is the case. Unfortunately, there has been little influence of philosophical accounts of mathematical explanation in educational research, and vice versa. This project brought together philosophers of mathematics, epistemologists, psychologists, and mathematics educators to discuss how advancements in their respective fields could meaningfully contribute to the work on mathematical explanation where their fields intersect. In doing so, this project promoted new research networks between researchers of scholarly communities not normally in contact with each other, and helped developed a new field of scholarship and research.

In particular, this project helped advance our understanding of the notion of mathematical explanation in the fields of philosophy (e.g. by helping those investigating the relationship between the notions of explanation and understanding in mathematics) and education (e.g. by helping refine the characterization of what constitutes an effective explanation in the mathematics classroom). Furthermore, the project helped delineate the intersection between philosophical and mathematics education perspectives on the notion of mathematical explanation, by identifying facets of the notion that are of shared interest, as well as those those that are not. More broadly, this project has had a significant impact on the emerging (and very exciting) work occurring at the intersection of mathematics education and the philosophy of mathematical practice. By engaging speakers who are not only experts in the study of explanation and understanding from their own disciplinary perspective, but also open to crossing traditional disciplinary boundaries (e.g., open to using different theoretical and methodological traditions in their own work), the project has opened new avenues of research in the area. Indeed, a key outcome of the project is the publication of a special issue of The Journal of Mathematical Behavior, focusing on the intersections between mathematics education and the philosophy of mathematical practice. This issue features submissions from both mathematics educators and philosophers, promoting interdisciplinary research at the intersection of the two fields. Several of the submitted manuscripts were authored by workshop participants and center on the notion of mathematical explanation, and some are co-authored by philosophers and mathematics educators who first collaborated at the workshop. As such, the workshop served as a catalyst for the kind of interdisciplinary work ﻿this project was set out to promote.

The broader impacts of this project stem from the central role explanations play in both teaching and learning. Teachers routinely offer instructional explanations as part of classroom practice, addressing both the implicit and explicit questions of their students (we also know self-explanations, generated by learners to deepen their own understanding of a particular topic, are known to significantly enhance learning outcomes). However, despite the critical role of explanations in education, the question of what makes an explanation truly effective remains unresolved (indeed, explanations vary in quality, to the point where instructional explanations and self-explanations sometimes have negative effects). This is particularly true in the teaching and learning of mathematics, an area that is especially difficult for students to learn. In the medium- to long-term, we anticipate this project will have a significant impact on educational work on mathematical explanation, leading to new understandings and teaching methods and technologies that will ultimately impact teachers and students of mathematics at all educational levels. In the short-term, we anticipate that the many schoolteachers and community college professors who attended the event will have expanded and deepened their skills as educators. Participating and reflecting on the topics of this workshop will have helped them improve the quality of their explanations in the mathematics classroom.
